results.title: Early stone tools
results.creator_credit: Clyde B Smith and Extension Media Center, University of California
results.brief_description: Traces the development of stone tools and parallels their development with the evolution of man from austropithecus to homo sapiens. Demonstrates percussion flaking techniques to produce a variety of tools. Shows actual prehistoric tools.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clyde B Smith and Extension Media Center, University of California

results.title: Early Russian cinema. Vol 7: Evgenii Bauer
results.creator_credit: Evegnii Bauer and A Khanzhonov and Co
results.brief_description: Three short silent films by Soviet director Evegnii Bauer that explore themes of class, sexual politics, doomed love, grief and sanity. “A child of the big city” Mary, a seamstress with a meagre existence who dreams of a grander life of luxury and wealth, meets Victor, a well-do-do young man, who spurns his pretentious peers. Beguiled by the luxuries that pepper Victor’s world, Mary becomes flirtatious and develops a taste for decadent habits. Financially ruined and personally demoralised, Victor despairs at Mary’s transformation. This mournful, melancholy melodrama, and morality play, examines the notions of class and corrupting influence of money on character. “The 1102nd ruse” An elderly husband believes himself inured to the skilful wiles of women, to the frustration of his scheming wife. But she is determined to hoodwink him by inventing a cunning ruse unfamiliar to him. A slight comedy of manners that comments on the power of sexuality whilst gently mocking the sanctity of marriage. “Daydreams” A man, mourning the death of his wife, is soon romancing an actress who shares a likeness with his deceased beloved. As his obsession grows, he fears insanity and is beset by ghostly apparitions. All feature musical score, Russian intertitles and English subtitles.

results.title: Early Communication in Australia
results.brief_description: Challenged to create a moving image work on the theme ‘Pacific Explorer’, this highly commended work uses Australian stamps with historical and Aboriginal themes to narrate the methods and ways Australians have communicated over time. An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: Durga puja in Calcutta
results.creator_credit: Mriganka Sekhar Ray and Calcutta Film Society
results.brief_description: The monsoon is over…in Bengal it is time for the festival of Durga Puja, goddess of war, militant aspect of Parvati, consort of Shiva. Celebrations praise Durga’s victory over the buffalo demon Mahisasura symbolising triumph of good over evil. The film is an impressionistic view of this festival.

results.title: Dummy
results.brief_description: Pregnant with absence, ‘Dummy’ depicts desolate urban and suburban environments. Filmed in and around Melbourne, these everyday, expectant spaces are captured with formal elegance and an accidental beauty that reveals a unique insight into the secret and forgotten life of Melbourne.

results.title: Duke of Wellington
results.creator_credit: Frank Stevens, Clifford Parris and Film House Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “London No 1”.
A visit to Apsley House at Hyde Park Corner in London which belonged to the first Duke of Wellington and houses the Wellington Museum. It is known popularly as No. 1, London.

results.title: Duke Ellington at the White House
results.brief_description: A special guest performance of this world famous jazz man at the White House is captured in this film. Duke Ellington plays before distinguished guests and displays his great talent in what was virtually a ‘command performance’.
results.description: A special guest performance of this world famous jazz man at the White House is captured in this film. Duke Ellington plays before distinguished guests and displays his great talent in what was virtually a ‘command performance’.

results.title: Drunken boat = Bateau ivre
results.creator_credit: Alfred Chaumel, Henri Beauvais and Franfilmdis
results.brief_description: After the poems of J. Arthur Rimbaud and the symphony “Bateau Ivre” by Robert Bergmann. Prelude for two voices Simon Gantillon and the voice of Rimbaud is Jean-Luis Barrault. In French with no English subtitles.

results.title: Drugs Are Not the Problem
results.brief_description: In themselves drugs are not a problem but their abuse is. The film shows young people using various drugs and the penultimate consequence of addiction. There is a clear, diagrammatic representation of how the human mind and nervous system work and how drugs affect them. Above all, the film repeatedly points out that the human mind is capable of the greatest powers.
